newsitem.title: UK: Mahatma Gandhi's letters go on sale in London.
newsitem.headline: Mahatma Gandhi's letters go on sale in London.

text.p: A collection of writings by Indian nationalist leader Mahatma Gandhi, which were stashed in a cupboard in Madras for nearly 50 years, are to be sold in London, auction house Phillips said on Monday.
Many of the 450 handwritten papers are scrawled on the backs of envelopes or old letters by the environment-conscious leader.
They include many of the speeches Ghandi made in the six months before he was assassinated in 1948.
There are also letters written to Britain's wartime prime minister, Winston Churchill, and to Louis Mountbatten, the last British viceroy of India before independence in 1947.

Ghandi's former secretary, V. Kalyanam, kept the writings in his home and is now selling them to raise money for a Hindu charity, which wants to build a new temple. They are expected to raise up to one million pounds ($1.60 million).
The documents include a letter to Mountbatten in which Ghandi, who led 350 million Indians in a non-violent campaign against British rule, made clear his opposition to the division of India.
"I pointed out the initial mistake of the British being party to splitting India into two," Gandhi wrote.

But he added magnanimously: "It is not possible to undo the mistake. The very admirable doctrine of fair play...demands that I do not help the mistaken party to fancy that the mistake was no mistake."
A Phillips spokesman described the archive as "extraordinary." "It is difficult to over-emphasise the importance of something so central to the 20th century," he said.
